TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi abstract beforefieldinit DataConnectionCollection extends System.Object implements class System.Collections.IEnumerable
Public MustInherit Class DataConnectionCollection Implements IEnumerable
public ref class DataConnectionCollection abstract : System::Collections::IEnumerable

Docs.summary: Contains a data connection object corresponding to each data connection used within a form template.

remarks.para: Each data connection is used to retrieve data (inserted into the main data source or into a secondary data source) or to submit data.
A data connection used to retrieve or submit data for the main data source will correspond to one of the following data connection object types:
A data connection used to retrieve data for a secondary data source will correspond to one of the following data connection object types:
A data connection used only for submitting data will correspond to one of the following data connection object types:
To access a object for a particular kind of data connection, use the object associated with the form template. To access the object, use the property of the class.

To use the properties or methods of the object returned from the , you must cast that object to the type that represents the kind of data connection you are working with before you can access those members. For example, to work with an object (which represents a data connection for retrieving data from an Access or SQL Server database), you must cast the object returned from the as shown in the following examples.
remarks.code: ' Get the Employees connection from the ' DataConnections collection. Dim myAdoQueryConnection As AdoQueryConnection = _ DirectCast(Me.DataConnections("Employees"), AdoQueryConnection)
remarks.para: For more information about working with data connections, see How to: Access External Data Sources.

Public MustOverride ReadOnly Property Count As Integer
public: abstract property int Count { int get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the count of the number of objects in the collection.
Docs.value: The count of the number of objects in the collection.

remarks.para: This member can be accessed without restrictions.
This type or member can be accessed from code running in forms opened in Microsoft InfoPath Filler or in a Web browser.

example.para: In the following example, the count of the number of objects is displayed in a message box.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance class System.Collections.IEnumerator GetEnumerator() cil managed
Public MustOverride Function GetEnumerator () As IEnumerator

Docs.summary: Gets an object that iterates over all entries in the collection.

remarks.para: After you have set a reference to the object that the Item property returns, you can access any of its properties or methods after the object has been cast to the appropriate type for the corresponding data connection. For example, to access the properties and methods of an e-mail connection, you must cast the returned object to the type.
This member can be accessed without restrictions.
This type or member can be accessed from code running in forms opened in Microsoft InfoPath Filler or in a Web browser.

MemberSignature.Value: public abstract Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.DataConnection this[int index] { get; }
Default Public MustOverride ReadOnly Property Item(index As Integer) As DataConnection
public: abstract property Microsoft::Office::InfoPath::DataConnection ^ default[int] { Microsoft::Office::InfoPath::DataConnection ^ get(int index); };

Docs.param: The zero-based index of the object to get.
Docs.summary: Gets a reference to the specified object from the collection by index value.

remarks.para: After you have set a reference to the object that the Item property returns, you can access any of its properties or methods after the object has been cast to the appropriate type for the corresponding data connection. For example, to access the properties and methods of a data connection for submitting a form in e-mail, you must cast the returned object to the type.

Important: Index value of a given data connection is not guaranteed to be the same between versions, or between sessions of opening the same form template in InfoPath and in a Web browser (from an appropriately configured document library on SharePoint Server 2010 running InfoPath Forms Services). To reliably open the same data connection under all conditions, you should open the data connection explicitly by name using the method instead.
This member can be accessed without restrictions.
This type or member can be accessed from code running in forms opened in Microsoft InfoPath Filler or in a Web browser.

example.para: In the following example, the first object is retrieved from the , and then cast to the type.
example.code: ' Get the first connection from the ' DataConnections collection. Dim myEmailSubmitConnection As EmailSubmitConnection = _ DirectCast(Me.DataConnections(0), EmailSubmitConnection)

MemberSignature.Value: public abstract Microsoft.Office.InfoPath.DataConnection this[string name] { get; }
Default Public MustOverride ReadOnly Property Item(name As String) As DataConnection
public: abstract property Microsoft::Office::InfoPath::DataConnection ^ default[System::String ^] { Microsoft::Office::InfoPath::DataConnection ^ get(System::String ^ name); };

Docs.param: The name of the object to get.
Docs.summary: Gets a reference to the specified object from the collection by name.

remarks.para: After you have set a reference to the object that the Item property returns, you can access any of its properties or methods after the object has been cast to the appropriate type for the corresponding data connection. For example, to access the properties and methods of a data connection for submitting a form in e-mail, you must cast the returned object to the type.
This member can be accessed without restrictions.
This type or member can be accessed from code running in forms opened in Microsoft InfoPath Filler or in a Web browser.

example.para: In the following example, the object named "Employees" is retrieved from the , and then cast to the type (which represents a data connection for retrieving data from an Access or SQL Server database).
example.code: ' Get the Employees connection from the ' DataConnections collection. Dim myAdoQueryConnection As AdoQueryConnection = _ DirectCast(Me.DataConnections("Employees"), AdoQueryConnection)
